item.title: Worth your weight? Experimental evidence on the benefits of obesity in low-income countries.
item.description: ABSTRACT: In low-resource settings, where asymmetric information is widespread and verification technologiesare lacking, visible status goods may be exploited as cheap wealth screening devices. Obesity is visible, and in most low- income countries has the characteristics of a status good. In this paper, I test experimentally whether obesity has monetary benefits because it is exploited as a signal of wealth. To explore benefits I focus on credit markets. I estimate the causal effect of obesity by randomly assigning body mass using photo-morphed pictures in loan applications. The setting is Kampala, Uganda. In a field experiment with 124 financial institutions, I show that going from normal weight to obese improves access to credit as much as increasing oneâ€™s income by 60 percent. I pinpoint the mechanism by showing that reducing asymmetric information reduces obesity benefits. In terms of welfare consequences, a model of credit discrimination suggests that loan officers overrespond to obesity as compared to an unbiased discrimination benchmark. Further experimental evidence shows that lay people anticipate and overestimate obesity benefits, leading to additional demand distortions.
